terminologie_extrait.definition: A halfway shot between a lob and a loop/drive, played well off the table against an opponent’s aggressive drive, loop, or smash; ball crosses at least ~1 foot high with good topspin (sometimes sidespin), lands deep, and kicks outward.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Contrasted with high lobbing; emphasized to be kept lower (1–4 feet above net) and deep.

topspin_defense.probleme: Executing effective topspin defense from distance
causes_communes: Using a high lob instead of a lower, driving topspin that lands deep
Contacting under the ball (like a lob) rather than on the back of the ball
Keeping the ball too high, giving the opponent easy clearance

debutant: Start 8+ feet from the table; begin with racket just below ball; use a mostly forward, slightly upward stroke; contact the back of the ball.
Aim for a trajectory 1–4 feet over the net that lands deep and arcs down so the bounce kicks outward.
intermediaire: If you have a loop, think of it as a soft loop; if you are a counter-driver, think of it as a counterdrive with added topspin.
Add sidespin at times to vary the kick while maintaining depth and a relatively low arc.
avance: Blend trajectory control (height and depth) to reduce opponent’s smash clearance while keeping strong topspin so the ball shoots out after the bounce.
Alternate pure topspin and slight sidespin versions to disrupt the opponent’s rhythm.

exercices_complementaires.description: Feed or rally against smashes/loops from 8–12 ft back; contact the back of the ball; keep arc 1–4 ft above net; target deep endline; add occasional sidespin.

erreurs_a_eviter: Turning every defensive shot into a high lob with too much clearance
Contacting underneath the ball instead of on the back
Leaving the ball short so it doesn’t kick outward

backhand_sidespin_push.probleme: Adding and using a backhand sidespin push
causes_communes: Taking the ball too late, giving the opponent time to adjust
Applying only backspin without the lateral component
Overusing the shot and getting looped through due to reduced backspin

debutant: Start with racket a little above and to the right of the ball (for a right-hander).
Take the ball off the bounce to rush the opponent; stroke down and left-to-right to apply both backspin and sidespin.
intermediaire: Experiment with contact point: toward the bottom of the racket for quicker take; middle for more control.
Prioritize placement: to a right-hander’s wide backhand so the ball breaks into the backhand.
avance: Use against forehand sidespin serves to sidespin the return into the server’s wide backhand (righty vs righty).
Exploit lefty–righty matchups by breaking the ball into the wide forehand to pull the opponent out of position.

exercices_complementaires.description: Coach/mate serves short; receiver takes off the bounce with left-to-right stroke; alternate targets: wide BH, elbow, and surprise wide FH (in lefty–righty).

erreurs_a_eviter: Overusing the shot so opponents loop through the lighter backspin
Letting the ball rise (late contact) and losing the rushing effect
Aiming without accounting for the sidespin break

meta.article_title: Winning with Backspin for the Non-Chopper

winning_with_backspin_for_the_non_choppe.probleme: Using backspin effectively without being a dedicated chopper
causes_communes: Only serving backspin but not leveraging pushes in rallies
Pushing predictably in depth and spin
Failing to exploit short push to prevent opponent’s loop

debutant: Use short pushes so the ball would bounce twice; keep low to prevent easy attacks and elicit a long push to attack.
Employ long pushes occasionally to slow play and disrupt timing.
intermediaire: Vary push quality: heavy backspin for errors/weak shots; quick off-the-bounce pushes to rush opponents.
Exploit patterns: after forcing a forehand-from-backhand attack, quick-block to the open wide forehand or backhand.
avance: When forced off-table after a wide-forehand attack, use a reaching backhand chop to reset timing and regain position.
String quick pushes wide FH ↔ wide BH to catch opponents moving the wrong way and to choose your own attack ball.

exercices_complementaires.description: Alternate very short, low pushes with sudden deep, heavy and quick pushes to wide angles; partner tries to attack; receiver counters with planned quick-block placements.

erreurs_a_eviter: Letting pushes float high or medium-deep without purpose
Failing to vary spin (heavy vs no-spin) and timing (quick vs normal)

meta.article_title: Proper Use of the Back Shoulder

proper_use_of_the_back_shoulder.probleme: Incorrect back-shoulder position when switching between loop vs backspin and smash vs block
causes_communes: Loopers automatically dropping back shoulder on the following smash
Smashers failing to drop back shoulder when looping heavy backspin

debutant: When looping against backspin, drop the back shoulder (right shoulder for right-handers) to aid lifting.
On the next shot, if smashing a blocked return, keep the back shoulder up to avoid lifting long.

exercices_complementaires.description: Partner serves/pushes heavy backspin; player loops with back shoulder dropped; partner blocks; player keeps back shoulder up and smashes; repeat focusing on shoulder positions.

erreurs_a_eviter: Keeping shoulder high during lift vs backspin
Dropping shoulder into the smash after a loop and sending the ball long

relaxing_the_arm.probleme: Tension in the playing arm reduces power and control
relaxing_the_arm.diagnostic: Tight muscles in the playing arm fight the stroke and prevent proper motion.
causes_communes: Starting points with muscles already tight (jaw/shoulders/arm)
Attempting to guide strokes consciously during play

debutant: Take a long warm-up; before points, let the arm hang loosely; take a deep breath; relax jaw and shoulders; raise arms lightly into ready position.
If unable to relax, tense the arm maximally for ~5 seconds, then release to induce relaxation.
intermediaire: Use a self-check: imagine someone could easily move your arm up/down during the stroke; resisting indicates excess tension.

exercices_complementaires.description: Before serve/receive: arm dangle, deep breath, relax jaw/shoulders, lift arms lightly; optional 5-second maximal tension-release; begin rally maintaining loose feel.

erreurs_a_eviter: Starting strokes with tight arm muscles
Forgetting to relax shoulders and jaw which cue whole-body tension

meta.article_title: August 1, 2011 - Jerky Strokes and Jerkyitis: World's Most Rampant Table Tennis Disease

terminologie_extrait.definition: A tendency to make jerky, single-muscle, near full-power strokes that are hard to control; cannot be fully cured but can be controlled.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Addressed by not rushing, relaxing the arm, and avoiding conscious guiding during rallies.

august_1_2011_jerky_strokes_and_jerkyiti.probleme: Jerky strokes causing poor control and power application
august_1_2011_jerky_strokes_and_jerkyiti.diagnostic: Player uses mostly one muscle at near full power, rather than smoothly accelerating multiple muscles.
causes_communes: Rushing shots from being jammed at the table
Tensing the arm during incoming ball
Trying to consciously guide shots

debutant: Take a quarter- or half-step back to allow time for a relaxed, smooth stroke.
Before rallies, relax the arm at the side, then raise smoothly to ready; keep it relaxed during play.
intermediaire: Avoid consciously steering the ball; let trained mechanics execute.
Practice smoothness with random drills: start FH/BH only random, then expand to true random (middle and wide corners).

exercices_complementaires.description: Partner feeds balls randomly to FH or BH; player reacts with relaxed, non-guided strokes; progress to full randomness including middle and wide corners.

erreurs_a_eviter: Crowding the table and rushing every contact
Tensing the arm as the ball approaches
Over-guiding instead of trusting trained strokes

meta.article_title: April 25, 2011 - The Short Serve & Short Receive, and Looping

april_25_2011_the_short_serve_short_rece.probleme: Setting up your loop with short serve and short receive
causes_communes: Serving long and allowing opponent to loop first
Failing to keep short receive low, leading to flips or long pushes you can’t attack predictably

debutant: Serve short (often backspin) to elicit a long push that you can loop.
Practice recognizing short backspin serve, stepping in, and pushing short and low to set up a long push to loop.
intermediaire: Add short sidespin/topspin/no-spin serves; expect flip returns that are long and loopable, especially if your serve stays very low.
Accept early mistakes on short receive; with practice it becomes a repeatable setup.

exercices_complementaires.description: Alternate short backspin and short sidespin/no-spin serves; attack the long push or flip with a planned loop.
Partner serves short backspin; receiver steps in and pushes short and low; rally continues only if server’s next ball is long push; receiver loops.

erreurs_a_eviter: Serving long by mistake and giving away initiative
Pushing short without keeping the ball low enough

terminologie_extrait.definition: Bring the chopper close with short balls, then attack hard—especially to the middle—or fake and drop short again.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Serve and push short to draw in; attack when chopper is jammed over the table.

terminologie_extrait.definition: Control spin/pace with repeated softer topspins (not full spin) mostly into long pips, mixing pushes, then finish when a ball is right.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Vary spin (dead vs spinny) but anticipate heavier chop after heavy topspin.

terminologie_extrait.definition: Push a few, attack a selected ball, then push again—rarely attack twice in a row—until a putaway appears.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Favor attacking the middle; vary pushes to set up attacks.

terminologie_extrait.definition: Prolonged pushing with the chopper until they miss or pop one up.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Described as common at lower levels and not preferred for fun/learning.

playing_choppers.diagnostic: Choppers are weakest in the middle; corner and diagonal attacks give more margin; speed variations and drop shots can jam them.
causes_communes: Attacking predictably heavy spin and making errors
Failing to exploit the chopper’s middle
Letting the chopper control distance without using short balls

debutant: Target the middle frequently; use diagonals for margin; surprise down-the-line winners.
Serve/push short to bring the chopper in, then attack when they are jammed (European Style).
intermediaire: Vs long pips: repeat softer topspins into pips (not maximum spin), vary to dead/spinny, and mix occasional pushes; finish when ready (Asian Style).
Use pick-hitting: push a few, attack a chosen ball, then reset with a push; vary push depth/spin to set up next attack.
avance: Bend knees to near eye level with the ball to improve lifting consistency and tracking the spin.
Use short drops after deep returns to force in–out footwork, then attack into the middle as they rush.

exercices_complementaires.description: Rally vs chopper/feeder: alternate short drop to draw in, then next ball attacked into elbow/middle; reset and repeat.

erreurs_a_eviter: Looping heavy chop repeatedly without variation
Ignoring the chopper’s middle weakness
Over-pushing to the point your own timing degrades

meta.article_title: How To Play The Bomber: The Player Who Tries to Blast Every Shot

terminologie_extrait.definition: An opponent who tries to blast or smash virtually every ball.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Four counter-approaches: prevent attacks, induce misses, return shots, or match them.

terminologie_extrait.definition: Smart Bomber serves/receives short to attack first; Dumb Bomber neglects short receive and loses initiative.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Used to illustrate serve/receive priority in bomber mirror matches.

how_to_play_the_bomber_the_player_who_tr.probleme: Beating an all-out attacker who ‘gets hot’
causes_communes: Allowing easy attack balls (long/loose)
Letting the opponent find rhythm and repeat the same shot
Poor anticipation and late movement on putaways

debutant: Keep balls short and low (serve short, push short) to remove easy attacks.
Attack first with well-placed flips/loops/drives against pushes and short serves.
intermediaire: Disrupt rhythm by mixing spins, speeds, and placements; add no-spin after heavy backspin; vary pace mid-rally.
Improve anticipation: watch commitment, then move at the instant they are locked into a shot.
avance: If still overpowered, back off and return balls (lob, chop, scramble) to force extra swings and errors.
When matching bombers, prioritize serve/receive: serve mostly short; return short or place flips/long receives to attack first.

exercices_complementaires.description: Rally with programmed alternations: heavy push → sudden no-spin push; medium drive → surprise quick drive to middle; repeat to deny rhythm.

erreurs_a_eviter: Feeding predictable balls that let the bomber groove
Moving too early (telegraphing) or too late (no time) on their putaway
Serving long by accident and giving first attack

playing_against_combination_rackets.probleme: Handling anti-spin and long pips in pushes, chops, blocks, and drives
playing_against_combination_rackets.diagnostic: Anti deadens existing spin; long pips tends to reverse it. Reads must be based on prior spin.
causes_communes: Pushing anti like a normal backspin ball (contacting bottom and popping up)
Looping anti/LP returns without adjusting for reduced/dead or reversed spin
Attacking repeatedly into heavy LP chop after giving heavy topspin

debutant: Vs anti push: push by contacting the back of the ball; to loop, graze the top; expect shorter depth due to less backspin.
Vs anti block/drive: treat dead block like anti push (adjust to slower return); stroke up to add topspin vs dead/flat hits.
intermediaire: Vs long pips push: expect light topspin or dead depending on your prior push; attack short ones over the table; remember spin depends on your previous shot.
Vs long pips chop off loop: alternate powers, drop shots, and rolls; avoid repeated maximum-spin loops that bring back maximum chop.
avance: Tactics: Softly attack anti/LP until you get the right ball to go strong into the inverted side; target the middle (elbow) frequently.
Against Seemiller users: note which color/side is up; exploit fast flat serves to anti, esp. to the forehand; be ready for frequent anti receive.
Against shakehand combo: attack anti/pips repeatedly until a flip to inverted appears, then block back opposite; surprise fast serves to anti/pips side on receive.

exercices_complementaires.description: Feeder alternates anti and long pips strokes (push/chop/block/drive); receiver states expected spin based on previous ball, then executes correct counter (back contact push vs anti, lift vs dead drive, roll vs LP chop).

erreurs_a_eviter: Contacting under the ball vs anti pushes (popping up)
Looping hard repeatedly into LP heavy chop returns
Ignoring depth change (anti often returns shorter) and failing to adjust position
